senses.ex: The restaurant will hire more waiters to handle the rush hour crowd.

Tips.title: Job Offer Perspective
Tips.description: Refers to employer's action to provide a job, not the candidate's perspective of obtaining one.
Tips.example: The company plans to hire ten new employees next month.

Tips.title: Start of Employment
Tips.description: Implies the beginning of a working relationship, potentially long-term engagement.
Tips.example: After they hire you, you'll start with a training session.

Tips.title: Skill-based Selection
Tips.description: Indicates preference for specific skills or qualifications when hiring for a job.
Tips.example: We only hire experienced chefs who can handle the grill station.

senses.de: The act of hiring someone or something
senses.ex: His hire by the company was a controversial decision.

Tips.title: Focus on Process
Tips.description: Emphasizes the hiring process or event, rather than the individual hired.
Tips.example: The hire of the new manager took two months to finalize.

Tips.title: Not Always Positive
Tips.description: Can imply a controversial or questionable hiring decision.
Tips.example: Her hire raised quite a few eyebrows due to her lack of experience.

senses.de: To pay to use something for a short period
senses.ex: We decided to hire a car for our weekend getaway.

Tips.title: Temporary Possession
Tips.description: Stresses the short-term nature of the agreement for use of an item or service.
Tips.example: If you're only in town for a day, it might be best to hire a bike.

Tips.title: Cost Implication
Tips.description: Involves payment, often calculated by the hour or day, for temporary use.
Tips.example: How much does it cost to hire a kayak for an afternoon?

senses.de: A person who has been hired for a job
senses.ex: The new hires underwent a week of training before starting work.

Tips.title: New Addition
Tips.description: Refers to individuals recently recruited and joining a team or company.
Tips.example: All new hires must attend an orientation on their first day.

Tips.title: Training Period
Tips.description: Often implies a period of learning or probation for the person hired.
Tips.example: New hires are usually given extra support during the first few weeks.

Appoint.wordDefinition:
Appoint is usually used when someone is selected for a position or role, and they are given the authority to carry out certain tasks or responsibilities.

For example, a manager might appoint someone to lead a new project.

Appoint implies a more specific designation of duties or responsibilities, while hire is a more general term for bringing someone on to work for an organization.

Commission.wordDefinition:
Commission refers to a payment made to someone for completing a project or task. For example, an artist may be commissioned to paint a portrait for a client and will receive payment once the portrait is completed.

Generally, commission work is temporary and paid on a project basis.

Hiring is a long-term commitment, whereas commission work tends to be short-term or project-based.

Commission refers to a payment for a specific task or project, while hire refers to employing someone for a long-term position or job.

Contract.wordDefinition:
Contract and hire are both terms related to employment, but they are used in different situations.

Contract refers to a specific agreement between an employer and an employee, usually for a fixed period of time or project.

The terms of the agreement are outlined in a legal document, and both parties are bound to fulfill their obligations. For example, if a company needs a graphic designer to create a brochure, they may hire a freelance designer on a contract basis for a set fee and time period.

So, while contract is used for temporary or project-based work, hire is used for longer-term employment.

Employ.wordDefinition:
Both employ and hire have similar meanings but there are slight differences.

- Employ: This means to offer someone a job, giving them a particular role or responsibility.

It is usually used in a more formal setting, such as a company or organization. For example, "I am employed as a marketing manager at XYZ Corporation.".

So in short, if you are giving someone a long-term job with specific duties and responsibilities, use 'employ.' If you need someone to do a specific project or task temporarily, use 'hire.'

Engage.wordDefinition:
Engage means to involve someone in a task or activity, whereas the word hire means to pay someone for their services for a specific task or job.

For example, you would engage a friend to help you with a project, meaning you would involve them in the work.

Engage is more commonly used in casual or collaborative situations, while hire is used in professional or employment situations.

Lease.wordDefinition:
Lease means to rent something for a period of time, usually for a longer duration than hiring. For example, you can lease an apartment or lease a car.

You hire something or someone for a short-term use or employment, while you lease something for a longer-term rental agreement.

Recruit.wordDefinition:
Recruit means to seek and hire new employees.

Hire is used when an immediate position needs to be filled, and recruit is used when there is a need to look and select candidates for future job openings.

Rent.wordDefinition:
The words hire and rent both mean to pay for temporary use of something but hire is mostly used for services, professionals or people like hiring a plumber, a babysitter or an employee while rent is usually used for objects like renting a car, a house or equipment for a specific period of time.

Hire is used for people and services while rent is used for objects.

Utilize.wordDefinition:
Utilize means to make use of something for a specific purpose. For example, a company can utilize a software program to manage their finances.

Hire is used when referring to people and their employment status, while utilize is used when referring to resources or tools being used for a specific purpose.
